conclusion: The small car A is at the right edge, aimed left-upwards toward a loose cluster of single blocks (blue and green) and a three-block column (yellow–yellow–orange).
The blue/green blocks lie directly in the car’s path and are not attached to one another; they will move easily on contact.
The yellow column is taller and slightly wider than the car, so a glancing blow is expected rather than a head-on impact.
A’s front bumper hits the nearest loose cube (green).
Because the cubes are light and unanchored, they slide forward and slightly sideways, dispersing.
Momentum transfer slows the car only a little, so A keeps rolling.
After pushing through the small loose blocks, the car’s trajectory is now slightly deflected to the left by the uneven mass distribution of the cubes it just hit.
Instead of striking the yellow column squarely, A clips its front-right corner.
The column experiences a sideways impulse but, because the bottom orange block offers a broader base and friction with the cloth, the stack does not topple; it rocks and settles back almost upright.
The glancing impact from the column redirects A further leftward and drains most of its remaining kinetic energy.

A rolls a short additional distance, cushioned by the fabric surface, and comes to rest between the scattered blue/green cubes and the column—roughly where its rear wheels are just past the column’s front plane.
Blue/green cubes: spread out in a loose arc in front of and to the left of the car.
Yellow column: still standing, rotated a few degrees but not knocked down.
Orange cubes at left and red cubes at bottom: completely untouched.
Lone yellow cube at far left: untouched.
Car A: stationary, nose pointing slightly left of its original heading, located just to the right of the central blue/green scatter.

Car A plows through the blue and green cubes, scattering them forward and left, then glances off the yellow column, is deflected, and finally stops just to the right of the column while the column itself remains upright.
